| Section3 = {{Chembox Hazards Solubility = MainHazards = FlashPt =
| Autoignition =
  }} }} 'Carbamoyl phosphate' is an anion of biochemical significance. In land-
  dwelling animals it is an intermediary metabolite participating in the
  nitrogen disposal through in the urea cycle and the synthesis of pyrimidines.

It is produced from bicarbonate, ammonia (derived from glutamine), and phosphate
(from ATP). The synthesis is catalysed by the enzyme carbamoyl phosphate
synthetase, as follows:
